particular emphasis on using applied
mathematical techniques. He intends to use the
grant in part to support a post-doctoral research
associate and in part to be relieved of teaching
duties during one semester.

selected from 650 nominations by a committee
of distingtrished senior scientists.

President Richard Nixon, in a special report issued
over the weekend, stated a policy differing from that of
Reagans. Nixon. said that "physical intimidation" should
not be used to remedy- grievances on college campuses.
lie did indicate that clearly the task of dealing with

"The federal government," he continued, "cannot,

Hayakawa Speaks
Dr. S. I. Hayakawa, acting president of San
Francisco State College, today gave the Black Student
Union and its allies until April 11 "to demonstrate their
leadership in establishing peaceful conditions on
canipus."
He served notice at a news conference that he was
waiting until then to decide whether to invoke major
disciplinary penalties in the aftermath of the turbulent
strike that began on the campus on November 5. It
ended with an agreement announced March 20 after a
winter during which more than 600 arrests were made.
Dr. Hayakawa refused to withdraw the police
pending further developments. He won nationwide
attention with his "hard line" stand on the strike. When
asked whether he looked upon the campus as still in a
state of emergency, he replied, "I certainly do."
Dr. Hayakawa said that immediately after an
agreement had been announced "misunderstandings and
misinterpretations began to appear."
The agreement resulted from many discussions
between his own committee of faculty members and
administrators and negotiators representing the Black
Student Union and the Third World Liberation Front.

Columbia Aflame
The Columbia University chapter of Students for a
Democratic Society held a class boycott last Tuesday to
protest the activity of the school in domestic and
national affairs.
The students picketed several classroom buildings
on the Morningside Heights campus after holding a rally
at the center of campus. The action was completely
non-violent aside from occassional shouting matches
between students holding conflicting 453ints of view.
When individuals crossed the picket lines, participants
told the violators that they were strike braking, but took
no physical action to prevent persons from entering
buildings.
SDS challenged the University for its part in land
ownership in Harlem. They demanded that the proper ty
be put at the control of the community.
Also, the abolition of the Reserve Officers
Training Corps was called for by the radical students.
This demand is similar to those presented to the
administrations of several campuses across the nation.
Estimates of how successful the strike was are
varied. Sonic sources claimed that attendence was not
effected by the demonstration, but others said that forty
percent of the student body stayed away from their
classes.

Teens for Decency
Some 30,000 hand-clapping persons, some waving
signs saying "Down with Obscenity," rallied in the
Orange Bowl today to support a teen-age crusade for
decency in entertainment. Teenagers organized the rally
after Jim Morrison, the leader of the Doors, was charged
with indecent exposure during a concert in Miami on
March 1.
Teenage speakers gave three minute talks on God,
parents, patriotism, sexuality and brotherhood, "Five
Virtues," selected as the keynote of the rally, were
"belief in God and that He loves us: love of our planet
and country; love of our family; reverence of one's
sexuality; and equality of all men."
The shirt sleeved crowd basking in a warm sun
cheered for Jackie Gleason, Anita Bryant, and The
Lettermen, popular singers, who appeared in order to
applaud the teenage rally. "I believe this kind of
movement will snowball across the United States and
perhaps around the world," Mr. Gleason said.

School Bill Extended
House Education and Labor Committee voted over
Republican objections today to extend the Johnson
administration's major school aid bill until 1975.
Declaring that the Democratic controlled
committee was depriving the Nixon administration of a
chance to draw up its own school program;some
Republican members said they would try to get the
House to scale down the extension period.
The committee vote was 21 to 11 in favor of the
bill. No Democrats voted against it although Rep. Edith
Green (D. Ore) abstained. Two Republicans, Rep. Ogden
R. Reid of New York and Alphonzo Bell of California,
voted for it.
The bill extends for five years at a total cost of
$25 billion. Former President Johnson called it his
proudest legislative achievement. It gave federal grants to
local school districts to help them provide special
education for children from poor families.
